trips.title: Cowtown
trips.summary: My mom and I showed Karin around the Fort Worth Stockyards when we visited her before our trip to <abbr title="Southeast">S.E.</abbr> Asia. She had a blast checking out all them there Texans.

gallery.alt: A large silhouette statue of a historical figure in Texas.
gallery.comment: Big shoes to fill.

gallery.alt: There are two daily cattle runs in the Stockyards. It's a small ordeal, but fun to watch.
gallery.comment: The afternoon cattle run.

gallery.alt: People posing on a fake bull as if they were riding it.
gallery.comment: We went bull-riding!

gallery.alt: Woman posing in front of large pickup truck.
gallery.comment: Karin loved this Texas-sized truck.

gallery.alt: Panoramic photo of the stockyards where cattle are kept.

trips.title: Visiting Friends
trips.summary: We visited Jordan and Annette in Ann Arbor, Michigan. We had a fun week of hiking, canoeing, and furniture-building.
trips.content: <p>We visited our long-time friends Jordan and Annette at their new house in Ann Arbor, Michigan. Eric flew in from San Francisco too. We stayed for a week, just catching up.</p><p>They live near the Argo Canoe Livery along the Huron river and we went out on the water twice. The first time, Karin and I went with stand-up paddleboards while Jordan, Eric, and Annette went canoeing. The sun was hot but there were a few bridges offering some shade where we could take a break.</p><figure class="gallery  wide">            <span class="photo contain wide"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/ann-arbor-1.jpg); background-position: 0 80%; padding-bottom: 24%; "            title="A pelfie of the five of us. We stopped under a bridge to escape the sun for a while. From left to right: Karin, Jordan, Eric, Annette, Chris.">        <img src="/img/travel/ann-arbor-1.jpg"             alt="Picture of friends canoeing on a river."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/ann-arbor-2.jpg);  "            title="Karin and me.">        <img src="/img/travel/ann-arbor-2.jpg"             alt="People canoeing."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/ann-arbor-3.jpg);  "            title="Jordan lets Bama take the lead on the trail.">        <img src="/img/travel/ann-arbor-3.jpg"             alt="A man walking a dog."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/ann-arbor-4.jpg); background-position: 30% 0; "            title="Jordan, Annette, and Bama in their canoe.">        <img src="/img/travel/ann-arbor-4.jpg"             alt="A man and a woman in a canoe."             class="element-invisible">      </span>          </figure><p>The second time was after Eric had taken off, so Jordan and Annette took their pup Bama as a passenger while Karin and I rowed our own canoe.</p><p>We both agreed it&rsquo;s a little more work to row a canoe; with paddleboards you&rsquo;re the captain of a one-person vessel, but with a canoe there&rsquo;s teamwork involved. We&rsquo;ll have to try a few more times to find our rhythm, which I presume you have to find for each new partner you try canoeing with.</p><p>We also went hiking and geocaching in the nearby parks (Barton Nature Area and Bird Hill Nature Area). We were bummed that we didn&rsquo;t find any of the geocaches we hunted for, but it was still fun to try and find them.</p><p>We went to a few really great restaurants, but my favorite was <strong>Frita Batidos</strong>, serving cuban-inspired street food. The main attractions are chorizo hamburgers served with fried egg and shoestring fries on top, and shakes made of tropical fruits like coconut and mango (enhanced by a splash of dark rum, of course).</p><p>Karin wanted to visit an arcade while in the States, and we found <strong>Pinball Pete&rsquo;s</strong> to be the perfect mix of old and new. We played some classics like Pac-Man and Centipede and ended up winning some sweet prizes after playing Skee-ball and other ticket games. Karin walked away with a bouncy ball and a finger trap!</p>

gallery.alt: Picture of friends canoeing on a river.
gallery.comment: A pelfie of the five of us. We stopped under a bridge to escape the sun for a while. From left to right: Karin, Jordan, Eric, Annette, Chris.

gallery.alt: People canoeing.
gallery.comment: Karin and me.

gallery.alt: A man walking a dog.
gallery.comment: Jordan lets Bama take the lead on the trail.

gallery.alt: A man and a woman in a canoe.
gallery.comment: Jordan, Annette, and Bama in their canoe.

trips.title: Camping on the River
trips.summary: We spent the 4th of July in Val Maggia, a stunning valley with superb camping.

gallery.alt: Man overlooking a glacier-fed reservior in the Swiss Alps.
gallery.comment: Fed by glaciers, this reservior was one of many at the top of Val Maggia.

gallery.alt: An old church on a winding mountain road.
gallery.comment: This was typical scenery as we drove along the main road in the valley.

gallery.alt: Clean, fresh water from the river in Val Maggia.
gallery.comment: Our campsite, Campo Paradisio, was directly on this river. It had unbelievably clear water.

gallery.alt: Looking down upon Val Maggia from within a gondola heading toward the top.
gallery.comment: The gondola ride to the top of the mountains was gorgeous.

gallery.alt: A woman sits on the edge of a river.
gallery.comment: Karin overlooks our campsite's river. We couldn't get over how clean and pure the river was.

gallery.alt: A village high in the valley.
gallery.comment: The houses all looked so charming and similar. We later found out by speaking with some locals that the valley has a strict building code to enforce the old, weathered look.

trips.title: Graffiti
trips.summary: I went to Frontend United in Bristol. They had some sweet graffiti.

trips.title: Buccaneers
trips.summary: Our stop at Buccaneers was our last of the trip because it was so great! We stayed several days longer than we planned. It's a beautiful community situated across the entire side of a mountain facing the coast of Cintsa Bay.
trips.content: <figure class="gallery  tall">            <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/buccaneers-1.jpg); background-position: 36% 0; "            title="We had a private hut with a georgeous view of the bay!">        <img src="/img/travel/buccaneers-1.jpg"             alt="Overlooking Cintsa Bay from a hut at Buccaneers lodge."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/buccaneers-2.jpg);  "            title="The 'View of Africa' breakfast room at Buccaneers.">        <img src="/img/travel/buccaneers-2.jpg"             alt="A breakfast room with a balcony overlooking an ocean."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/buccaneers-3.jpg); background-position: 0 30%; "            title="The bridge that took us from the beach to the lodge.">        <img src="/img/travel/buccaneers-3.jpg"             alt="Wooden bridge leading to land."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/buccaneers-5.jpg);  "            title="There was lots of great sea life on this beach.">        <img src="/img/travel/buccaneers-5.jpg"             alt="Ocean life growing on a rock on the beach."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/buccaneers-4.jpg);  "            title="The rocky parts of the beach were full of life and interesting treasures. The terrain itself was quite interesting too.">        <img src="/img/travel/buccaneers-4.jpg"             alt="Panoramic of a rocky part of Cintsa beach."             class="element-invisible">      </span>          </figure>

gallery.alt: Overlooking Cintsa Bay from a hut at Buccaneers lodge.
gallery.comment: We had a private hut with a georgeous view of the bay!

gallery.alt: A breakfast room with a balcony overlooking an ocean.
gallery.comment: The 'View of Africa' breakfast room at Buccaneers.

gallery.alt: Wooden bridge leading to land.
gallery.comment: The bridge that took us from the beach to the lodge.

gallery.alt: Ocean life growing on a rock on the beach.
gallery.comment: There was lots of great sea life on this beach.

gallery.alt: Panoramic of a rocky part of Cintsa beach.
gallery.comment: The rocky parts of the beach were full of life and interesting treasures. The terrain itself was quite interesting too.

trips.title: Amakhala Game Reserve
trips.summary: We enjoyed a luxurious, thrilling safari on the Amakhala Game Reserve. We saw four of the Big 5 in their natural habitats, living freely under the protection of the game park we visited.
trips.content: <figure class="gallery  wide">            <span class="photo wide"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-1.jpg); background-position: 0 38%; "            title="Our view as we drove throughout the park.">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-1.jpg"             alt="Viewing the wilderness from a land rover."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-2.jpg); background-position: 35% 0; "            title="Our guide, Learnmore, who went by Lenny for short. He was extremely knowledgable and bold, getting us as close to the animals as possible while keeping us safe.">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-2.jpg"             alt="A park guide for Amakhala."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-3.jpg);  "            title="">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-3.jpg"             alt="Zebras grazing in a field."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-4.jpg);  "            title="">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-4.jpg"             alt="Facing the sunset in a field."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-5.jpg); background-position: 50% 0; "            title="We spotted this family of rhinos lined up just perfectly.">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-5.jpg"             alt="Three rhinos."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-6.jpg);  "            title="The lion was protecting a recent kill that was noticed the day before in the morning, but the lioness was fairly comfortable with us observing her two cubs. Eventually she shooed them off into the bushes but we got to watch them for at least 15 minutes.">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-6.jpg"             alt="A lioness and two cubs."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-9.jpg); background-position: 25% 0; "            title="Look, there's a giraffe on the left!">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-9.jpg"             alt="A giraffe grazing on a tree."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-8.jpg);  "            title="Eventually the matriarch got annoyed with us, most likely attempting to defend the newborn that was with them. We watched the elephants for about 20 minutes because they were occupying the only path back to our lodge, and we had to let all of them cross the road first">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-8.jpg"             alt="An elephant approaching our vehicle."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/amakhala-7.jpg);  "            title="This herd was probably 30 strong, with the matriarch easily identifiable due to a transponder placed on her head.">        <img src="/img/travel/amakhala-7.jpg"             alt="A herd of elephants grazing in a field."             class="element-invisible">      </span>          </figure>

gallery.alt: Viewing the wilderness from a land rover.
gallery.comment: Our view as we drove throughout the park.

gallery.alt: A park guide for Amakhala.
gallery.comment: Our guide, Learnmore, who went by Lenny for short. He was extremely knowledgable and bold, getting us as close to the animals as possible while keeping us safe.

gallery.alt: Zebras grazing in a field.
Facing the sunset in a field.
Three rhinos.
gallery.comment: We spotted this family of rhinos lined up just perfectly.

gallery.alt: A lioness and two cubs.
gallery.comment: The lion was protecting a recent kill that was noticed the day before in the morning, but the lioness was fairly comfortable with us observing her two cubs. Eventually she shooed them off into the bushes but we got to watch them for at least 15 minutes.

gallery.alt: A giraffe grazing on a tree.
gallery.comment: Look, there's a giraffe on the left!

gallery.alt: An elephant approaching our vehicle.
gallery.comment: Eventually the matriarch got annoyed with us, most likely attempting to defend the newborn that was with them. We watched the elephants for about 20 minutes because they were occupying the only path back to our lodge, and we had to let all of them cross the road first

gallery.alt: A herd of elephants grazing in a field.
gallery.comment: This herd was probably 30 strong, with the matriarch easily identifiable due to a transponder placed on her head.

trips.title: J-Bay
trips.summary: Jeffreys Bay is a popular surfing spot with great beaches. We took it easy here and just enjoyed the scenery.

trips.title: Relaxing on the beach
trips.summary: Mossel Bay is the east bookend of the Garden Route, offering a relaxing string of beaches. It's great for a private getaway.
trips.content: <p>Mossel Bay was one of our only stops along the Garden Route. We stayed in Cape Town as long as possible and as a result saw much of the Route from the car.</p><p>We found a charming <abbr title="Bed and Breakfast">B&amp;B</abbr> called <em>Lillies &amp; Leopards</em> on the south-facing edge of the bay. It was fairly close to a private beach, whose waters were a bit too rough to go swimming that day. Happy to just relax and watch the sunset, we stayed out until it was dark.</p><p>We found these strange slugs all over the beach feeding on jellyfish. Karin couldn&rsquo;t stand to look at them, and dubbed them &ldquo;grossies&rdquo;</p><figure class="gallery  tall">            <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/mossel-bay-1.jpg);  "            title="Our balcony view from Lillies & Leopards">        <img src="/img/travel/mossel-bay-1.jpg"             alt="An apartment view of the beach."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/mossel-bay-2.jpg);  "            title="the grossies">        <img src="/img/travel/mossel-bay-2.jpg"             alt="Slugs feeding on a deceased jellyfish."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/mossel-bay-3.jpg);  "            title="Gotta get one good jumping picture in for our trip!">        <img src="/img/travel/mossel-bay-3.jpg"             alt="Man's silhouette jumping off a rock."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/mossel-bay-4.jpg);  "            title="Wonderful conclusion to our evening.">        <img src="/img/travel/mossel-bay-4.jpg"             alt="A sunset on the beach."             class="element-invisible">      </span>          </figure><p>The next morning we planned to hit the road again, momentarily tempted to stay another day when Gaby cooked us our spectacular three-course breakfast: beginning with fruits, cereal, and yogurt; toast with a number of delicious homemade spreads; and finally Gaby offered us eggs, mushrooms, and bacon.</p><p>Gaby was a delightful woman, born in South Africa but over her life had fallen in love with the German language. She was eager to help us find activities, and maintained a truly lovely B&amp;B for travellers.</p><p>We really enjoyed our short stop in Mossel Bay. I&rsquo;d recommend <em>Lillies &amp; Leopards</em> to any couple looking for a cozy, private spot along the Garden Route.</p>

gallery.alt: An apartment view of the beach.
gallery.comment: Our balcony view from Lillies & Leopards

gallery.alt: Slugs feeding on a deceased jellyfish.
gallery.comment: the grossies

gallery.alt: Man's silhouette jumping off a rock.
gallery.comment: Gotta get one good jumping picture in for our trip!

gallery.alt: A sunset on the beach.
gallery.comment: Wonderful conclusion to our evening.

trips.title: Lion's Head
trips.summary: Lion's Head is an easy hike for people of all skill levels. We easily made the top in about an hour, and we heard it's a good spot for night hiking too.
trips.content: <figure class="gallery  tall">            <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/lions-head-1.jpg); background-position: 70% 0; "            title="The colors of the rocks on Lion's Head were so vivid.">        <img src="/img/travel/lions-head-1.jpg"             alt="Colorful rocks on a mountain."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/lions-head-2.jpg); background-position: 0 40%; "            title="Clifton 4th beach, where we hung out our first night.">        <img src="/img/travel/lions-head-2.jpg"             alt="The ocean, viewed from upon a mountain."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/lions-head-3.jpg);  "            title="Karin and I walked down the opposite trail after climing to the top.">        <img src="/img/travel/lions-head-3.jpg"             alt="Woman walking downhill on a trail."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/lions-head-4.jpg);  "            title="The view from Mark's apartment that evening. A fitting end to the day.">        <img src="/img/travel/lions-head-4.jpg"             alt="Lion's Head at twilight."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/lions-head-5.jpg);  "            title="One of my favorite pictures of the trip. It captures the table cloth so well!">        <img src="/img/travel/lions-head-5.jpg"             alt="Man posing at the top of Lion's Head."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                        <figcaption>Lion&rsquo;s Head was quite easy-going compared to India Venster, but it was no less beautiful.</figcaption>      </figure>

trips.title: Setting the table
trips.summary: We hiked the India Venster on Table Mountain. It was an intense, challenging hike because we went off the trail.
trips.content: <p>Capetown was the beginning of our trip through South Africa. We picked it because Mark had just moved there. We wanted to visit him after <a href="http://tunafish.es">his trip</a> took him from Austin all the way down to Patagonia and back to Durban.</p><p>Our first full day, Mark wanted to take us hiking. There was a concert near Table Mountain that evening so we were going to meet some friends after hiking around the mountain for the afternoon. He picked the <em>India Venster</em>, one of the more difficult — but beautiful — trails on Table Mountain.</p><p>We got started fairly late, around 11am. It was already hot, but for an hour or two hike we had good supplies: ~1.5L of water apiece, and lots of food since we planned for lunch on the trail.</p><p>Unlike most folks we skipped the cable car and began the hike up Table Mountain. After an hour or so, we stopped to eat. Although we&rsquo;d seen many people on the trail, only one lone hiker passed us at our lunch spot. He looked dreadfully thirsty and admitted he wasn&rsquo;t sure that he was on the trail. Mark assured him it was not too long before the end and told him to keep on going. After we ate, we packed up and kept moving too.</p><p>Shortly after lunch, we approached a beautiful gulch which we thought was the actual India Venster. The view was stunning and we were happily taking photos left and right:</p><figure class="gallery  wide">            <span class="photo wide"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/table-mountain-1.jpg);  "            title="Enjoying the views of India Venster.">        <img src="/img/travel/table-mountain-1.jpg"             alt="People hiking a vast mountainside."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/table-mountain-2.jpg); background-position: 0 30%; "            title="Right after our lunch break before turning around the other side of Table Mountain.">        <img src="/img/travel/table-mountain-2.jpg"             alt="A woman and a man on an upwards path."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/table-mountain-3.jpg); background-position: 0 85%; "            title="What we thought was the India Venster... it was just another gulch.">        <img src="/img/travel/table-mountain-3.jpg"             alt="a gulch revealing another mountain range."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/table-mountain-4.jpg);  "            title="">        <img src="/img/travel/table-mountain-4.jpg"             alt="Looking to the southwest as we traverse one of the 12 apostles of Table Mountain."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/table-mountain-5.jpg);  "            title="Turning the corner on one of the apostles. Can you even see the others?">        <img src="/img/travel/table-mountain-5.jpg"             alt="Mountainside."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                        <figcaption>Photos along the <em>India Venster</em> — or so we thought.</figcaption>      </figure><p>After a while, though, it became clear that we weren&rsquo;t on the trail anymore. We hadn&rsquo;t seen another soul, save for the fellow that passed us at lunch&hellip; but we&rsquo;d caught up with him and he joined our party. He was Dutch, named Anthony.</p><p>We hiked and scrambled along some very narrow paths, with absolutely no chains or cables in sight. It was pretty harrowing to look down while crossing a few tight spots. In others, we were scrambling around rocks, or making small jumps over very deep drops. Our panic was well-managed, but slowly creeping up on us.</p><p>We were also running out of water, and Anthony was long past finished with his. Mark kept running up ahead to try and find an indication of the trail, and we&rsquo;d slowly plod along, wondering where exactly he&rsquo;d trekked over the untamed terrain in front of us. Occasionally we&rsquo;d find little piles of stones that previous hikers had left, but it was hours since we&rsquo;d found the yellow paint footprints that marked the beginning of the trail.</p><p>Anthony started admitting what a situation he was in, which was a bit worse than ours. For starters, he had been out drinking the night before, and was hungover in the morning. He didn&rsquo;t eat breakfast save for some candy, and he&rsquo;d only brought a liter of water. He wasn&rsquo;t wearing a shirt, and the sun was <em>beating</em> on us the whole time.</p><p>Then&hellip; he swallowed a fly while we were hiking. When he was hacking away on it I started to really worry if we&rsquo;d have to call a helicopter for him&hellip; and us.</p><p>The hike went on, slowly but surely. Mark was urging us to keep moving, worried that we&rsquo;d give up hope. But my energy was low and I needed frequent rest. In order to cut some time off our ascent, Mark took us up some steep ways; we thought we might just hit a road or main trail again, but several times we scrambled up a rocky hill only to find more rocks staring downward at us.</p><p>After several unplanned hours of trudging along, we finally hit level ground, marking the top of Table Mountain. We were hugging each other we were so happy. About a kilometer later we found an unmarked wood-plank path.</p><p>Marching on another 20 minutes we found a sign for&hellip; the India Venster 😆</p><figure class="gallery  wide">            <span class="photo contain wide"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/table-mountain-6.jpg);  "            title="After a long hike we were rewarded with this spectacular view of the Indian Ocean.">        <img src="/img/travel/table-mountain-6.jpg"             alt="Facing the Indian ocean from the top of Table Mountain."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                    <span class="photo"            style="background-image: url(/img/travel/table-mountain-7.jpg); background-position: 0 32%; "            title="">        <img src="/img/travel/table-mountain-7.jpg"             alt="Happy couple posing in front of Lion's Head from the top of Table Mountain."             class="element-invisible">      </span>                        <figcaption>Although we went very far off the trail, the day ended in success. We finished the long day with a beautiful view of Cape Town including <em>Lion&rsquo;s Head</em> mountain and Robben Island.</figcaption>      </figure><p>It wasn&rsquo;t too long until we were back in the thick of the tourism near the cable car. We gladly blended into the crowd, grabbing ice cream and drinks, feeling lucky to be alive. Our cable car ride to the bottom was pleasantly uneventful.</p><p>We later figured out that we&rsquo;d gone off the trail even before sitting down for lunch, which is why Anthony was the only other hiker we saw after our meal. In total, we hiked around three of the 12 apostles, and the real Venster takes hikers around none! </p><p>With the whole ordeal behind us, it was invigorating and made us feel quite accomplished. It raised my tolerance for hiking situations, and made me appreciate having proper supplies for a given trek.</p>

gallery.comment: What we thought was the India Venster... it was just another gulch.

Mountainside.
gallery.comment: Turning the corner on one of the apostles. Can you even see the others?
